title: What will Uber's end-of-day market capitalization be on 31 December 2021?
possible_answers: More than $100 billion but less than $125 billion
preds:
Potential resistance around $43.50.
Losing $41.50 would be a concern that would force a sizeable adjustment.
Potential double bottom just confirmed. Still needs to break $40.

There are some positive growth factors, including making a profit third quarter this year, the more than doubling of revenue during the last year and 30 to 50 percent per year growth per year pre-pandemic.    However, the challenge ends in two weeks and delta cases are rising in the US.  Omicron is also spreading fast.   Hence, I suspect those two factors will keep the price down for another two weeks.

Uber has already a high of a market cap.
Based on normal biz models, Uber has capitalized in the promotion of another crack-job by the American lazy political and regulatory oversite approach, its capitalization has nothing to do with any rational biz model, other than that preys on the absurd incompetences of policy makers. That is my view and I am sticking to it!
It's currently $71 billion with 14 trading days remaining.
Capitalization as of dec 9 is just above 73 billion. Wondering if the holidays will have a positive effect.

Uber just lost a $2.8 billiion lawsuit in the UK and will have to re-classify its UK drivers as employees.  I thought this negative news would blow over in a few weeks since Uber made a profit in the third quarter and the UK accounted for a relatively small percentage of its total revenue in 2020, Europe, the Middle East and Africa accounted for $2.09 billiion out of $11.15 billion total revenue.  I could not find a further breakdown to just Europe, but I will assume at least 2/3's of the revenue came from Europe.  If so, only about 10 percent of total revenue came from Europe and of course, less came from just the UK, maybe three to eight percent of Ubers' total revenue. However, the EU just introduced a bill reclassifying all EU Uber and Deliveroo drivers (a company Uber and Amazon use to make deliveries) as employees.  I suspect this news will put further downward pressure on the stock price.  Thus, the market cap could remain lower than $75 billion  for at least the next three weeks, even though the proposed might not affect overall future profitability as much as it might seem at first. https://www.wsj.com/articles/uber-amazon-backed-deliveroo-workers-would-be-classed-as-employees-under-eu-proposal-11639044561#:~:text=Uber%20Technologies%20Inc.%2C%20Amazon.%20com%20Inc.-backed%20Deliveroo%20PLC,would%20reclassify%20many%20of%20their%20jobs%20as%20employment. https://businessquant.com/uber-revenue-breakdown-worldwide#:~:text=Uber%E2%80%99s%20revenue%20from%20Europe%2C%20Middle%20East%2C%20and%20Africa,this%20region%20contributed%2018.74%25%20to%20Uber%E2%80%99s%20total%20revenue.

It looks like Uber's recent price decline had as much to do with losing a $2.8 billion lawsuit and the UK requiring the re-clasification of it's drivers as it did with the new covid variant.  Uber made a operating profit in the third quarter for the first time--and during covid.  So, I think the price will likely increase as the shock of losing such a large case and the fear of the omnicon variant decline.   I heard on NPR that according to a Japanese study released today the omnicon variant is about 4.3 times more contagious than the delta variant (whatever that means), but much less dangerous according to Dr. Fauci.   https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-06/uber-suffers-another-blow-over-drivers-rights-in-u-k-court?sref=S6StyAN1

Seems like a coin toss to me. UBER is currently right around $75B market cap. Uber is trending down. VV (large cap) is trending up. December is historically a bullish month. Lots of volatility in equities lately.
It’s below 70B now, it’s in toss-up territory for the $75 break point.  Nudging low based in current price n
Stochastic simulation. Which I find amusing in a rather disturbing way every time a tech giant tanks.

Making a sharp adjustment from previous forecast. Previous Q was relatively flat in intuitional buying. Valuation is nearing its lowest level for 2021. Unless Uber announces incredible news there may not be many factors to get the stock to pop up before the end of the year. https://whalewisdom.com/stock/uber
the September low (~$39.50) is my pivot point. See how it reacts to the $37 mark this week and then I'll make an adjustment one way or the other!
Same as today with some variability
Shifted my bias to the downside. A minor tweak but could be an important one. <$40 and my bias shifts more extremely.
adjusting based on today's price actions.
Tightening distribution as resolution date approaches. Current market cap is 77.45B, just barely into the second bin
revising as time passes by, increase 2nd bucket
Becoming more confident as time passes

Mostly positive news from latest earnings call, profitability is still in the red. the market didn’t immediately agree with Uber’s numbers and the valuation is staying slightly the same after hours. The market is frothy, I have doubts that institutional money will be pouring money into uber over the next month and a half. https://investor.uber.com/news-events/news/press-release-details/2021/Uber-Announces-Results-for-Third-Quarter-2021/
Updating for share price jump a couple of days ago

https://finance.yahoo.com/news/lyft-reports-adjusted-profit-riders-200721684.html Uber stock rose 3 pts today, tomorrow is their earnings call. "Uber has said it expects to break even on an adjusted EBITDA basis for the first time."
I calculated that the current market cap is above its intrinsic value by a small to moderate margin.
Stochastic simulation of 49 market closes with log-normally distributed daily price movements. Spot price used for starting point and variance from historical close data.

Recent earning calls have exceed expiations as Uber continues to post larger gains year over year (2020). The next earning release is expected to beat expiations. Valuation will likely fluctuation up based on improved business fundamentals. Instructional ownership has increased for 2021, this could also push the valuation closer to 100B.
  Market Cap history
https://ycharts.com/companies/UBER/market_cap Institutional Ownership tracking
https://whalewisdom.com/stock/uber

Still getting my information from https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/UBER/. Still assuming that the total outstanding shares are unchanged by the end of this question. The profitability of the company jumped on 9/20 and that requires that I update this with the new information. Still concerned about potential rulings against the company, but those are not very likely in the 2.5 months we have left. We're going to be close around the $100B cap of $53.48 but I'm a pessimist on these things so I'm taking the under. If the economy tanks again we could also see the market, in general, crash and take Uber with it. Pricing chart based on 1.87B shares outstanding:
$75B - $40.11
$100B - $53.48
$125B - $66.85
$150B - $80.22
next earnings call is scheduled Nov 4, last one inside the forecast range. last call resulted in a 3 pt jump in the stock price that was quickly erased. current market cap: 91.3bn.
Update.  $51 is a pivot point for my bias.

Valuation expansion has not extended past 100B over the past year too often for Uber however recent earning reports in 2021 have beat expectations and Q3 earnings that are lapping 2020 Q3 could increase market activity with positive numbers https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/UBER/key-statistics?p=UBER
price at 47.77 and market cap at 90 BUSD

Uber's market cap is currently $84.42B with a per-share price of $44.80. We would need a ±10% move at minimum for Uber's market cap to hit $75B or $100B. I don't think there will be any Uber-specific news events in the next 3 months that could cause a major stock move. I also don't think there will be any major macroeconomic events that could majorly move stocks at large. E.g. I don't think the Fed will majorly change the liquidity that they're providing to markets. Not in the next 3 months, at least.
Reiteration. I have a bias pivot at $37.

I definitely was way off here. Current trends: As more judges (in California and Netherland for example) are ruling that Uber drivers are employees and not contractors, profit could drop for Uber.
I've also read somewhere that they are facing shortage of drivers. 
I need to do more research here. But for now I'm adjusting my initial estimate (which was way off)

>$41 pivots my bias higher
<$36 pivots my bias lower

Continuing to post this chart because it is an easier basis to understand than their market cap since it is unlikely that they issue new shares. S&P 500 is at a 19% gain this year while Uber is at a 22% loss over that same time period. With this in mind and the $39.86 current stock price, I am going to decrease my expected value and move the chances of LT $75B and $75B-$100B upwards while decreasing the chances of $100B-$125B even. Still 4.5 months to go which can drastically swing a price, but the Delta variant continues to weigh on the nation. Pricing chart based on 1.87B shares outstanding:
$75B - $40.11
$100B - $53.48
$125B - $66.85
$150B - $80.22
Aligning more for crowd but Uber downtrend w/ overall market hitting ATH is very bearish IMO.  Lockdown/delta threats pose serious risk to the downside ATM.
At $83B now, but declining. Unlikely to reach $100B, drop below 75 is a real possibility.

Continuing to post this chart because it is an easier basis to understand than their market cap since it is unlikely that they issue new shares. S&P 500 is at a 16.96% gain over the past 6 months while Uber is at a 5% loss over that same time period. With this in mind and the $45 current stock price, I am going to decrease my expected value and move the chances of LT $75B and $75B-$100B upwards while decreasing the chances of $100B-$125B and $125B-$150B. Still 6 months to go which can drastically swing a price, but the Delta variant is implying less need/desire for travel in the upcoming months. Pricing chart based on 1.87B shares outstanding:
$75B - $40.11
$100B - $53.48
$125B - $66.85
$150B - $80.22

Currently 86.9 billion market cap $40.06/shr represents a market cap of 75 billion.  $53.42/shr is 100 billion.  $66.77/shr is 125 billion.   I lean bearish on Uber for many reasons right now primarily the competition in self driving cars and their lack of demand over the past year but also how expensive rides have been recently, lack of supply, and general macro trends (delta, etc.).  OTOH possibility of continued reopening.  I do expect Uber to have a better year compared to last, I do not anticipate it being anything near 2019 levels.

Pricing chart based on 1.87B shares outstanding:
$75B - $40.11
$100B - $53.48
$125B - $66.85
$150B - $80.22 Still thinking price will be above $53.48 by the end of the year, but it has plummeted from the $63.18 peak that it was at and we seem to be settling into a lower range for the moment. I'll continue to monitor both UBER and the market as a whole. Breakout north is more likely than a plummet based on overall market sentiment and the world economies opening back up. Delta variant causing some headaches with that.
It's expected the share price end up somewhere between 70 to 80, which puts the market cap between 130 to 150. Currently - June 5 - share price is at 51.71 (market cap: 97.11 BUSD).
It's a $95B now. It's not clear how this company grows with the current labor situation and higher fares.  The overall market seems to be heading higher though, which could push it over $100B.

Refining initial estimate.  At $95 bn today, market cap has ranged from $82 - 120 bn YTD (~ -15% to +25%). That seems a fair range for the stock over the next six months, with a slight bias to the upside given analysts positive ratings and price targets [1].   Helpful perspectives  from @Prem_Fan_2021 [2] and @Skyreichel [3]. [1] https://www.wsj.com/market-data/quotes/UBER/research-ratings
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1227924
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1286404
Expect some increase to around record highs (c. 120bn) as Californian-style fudge on worker status is worked out. Will be volatile – monitor weekly
Revised upward given recent price changes
will stay same as it is right now. No major announcements expected; increase in revenue offset by negative cash flows

Uber seems to be trading around 50/share which is a 95B marketcap. It will likely rise slowly in Q3/Q4 towards 60; maybe periodically eclipsing the figure but with the dip around NYE, it should fall around 95-115B. That would be my pick. 
It won't eclipse 150 because as Uber rides increase, Uber eats will decrease (no causation, simple correlation of trends) and the 2% for less than 75 is simply hedging from a contract dispute/bankruptcy/incompetency.
Again this growth would be in line with any Ponzi scheme.

Market Cap = Shares Outstanding x Price Per Share. Shares Outstanding for Uber are approximately 1.87B and I don't think that will necessarily change before we get to December - though I'd be interested in why it did if they do end up diluting or buying back shares. So taking all that into account, we are somewhat trying to predict the market price of an Uber share as of December 2021. To give everyone an idea of what prices would need to be for each level:
$75B - $40.11
$100B - $53.48
$125B - $66.85
$150B - $80.22 Looking at the indices that hold UBER, we see that the Vanguard Total Market and Vanguard Extended ETF are some of the larger ones, holding around $500M between them. So one major disruption to price would be Uber's inclusion in the S&P 500 index which would require a TON of different places to buy shares and thus send the stock skyward- very, very unlikely. We also have to wonder about the overall market health in December. I think we are seeing a period of stagnation where there are no major economic disruptions on the horizon, but that always means we have to be aware that a major event like COVID could still happen even at an extremely low rate. Uber is a stock that should do better when times are good because people are more willing to take rides and go places. Anyway, Uber hit a 5-year high on 2/12 at 60.63 and they peaked near that a couple times after that at 60.35. I'm pretty sure we will see fluctuations in the price, but the most likely scenario given the current data is that it hovers somewhere around where it is now.

There is a risk that inflationary pressure will push up borrowing costs and for growth stocks this will push down the share price. Also to survive Covid Uber sold off a lot of their assets that were in development (flying taxis, driverless cars) I think this will significantly hurt their growth prospects.
don't have enough facts to guess
stockmarkets are in for a slower year + realisation that the business model needs revamping to be sustainably profitable

Current market cap is 88.76B. A lot of unknowns and moving parts.
+ Uber might become profitable (though that doesn't mean its stock price will increase), https://techcrunch.com/2021/05/05/ubers-mixed-q1-earnings-portray-an-evolving-business/
- stock market is in shaky territory given inflation concerns, Fed positioning, etc.
- rotation from growth/tech into value
+ reopening and a revival of the ride-sharing aspect (though again, this doesn't mean stock price will go up)
- reopening and a decrease in delivery bookings (ditto for stock price going down)
- lawsuits, ongoing questions about employee vs contractor, and how these affect Uber's business model
+ fiscal stimulus and continued QE Overall, I think there are more potential surprises to the downside than the upside.

Seems heavily overpriced at the minute to me but then company valuations are all over the place at the minute. There might be a market correction. Lots of factors make this quite tricky to call so favouring the status quo. Various court cases in the UK and concerns about drivers rights might give people cause for concern and speculative shorting might have an impact. Post lockdown opening up might result in increased revenues but other competitors are in the market and might be better placed....

It will no be able to substain this capitalization once the Fed stops the junk buying. 
The present risk market has nothing to do with viable corpoprations, is all about the governement intervention, once that starts to decline the music stops

Current market cap is 87.82B, the price of an individual share is 47.03. So there are 1,867,318,733 shares outstanding (I think?). 52-wk high	64.05	(119.6B)
52-wk low	28.39	(53.0B) Not sure if the shares outstanding varied and I'm doing the math wrong here. It's surprisingly hard to find historical market cap figures.
It’s at 87B right now. The market is pretty strong now, so it likely ends up above 75B

Uber actualmente capitaliza cerca de 113 millones de dólares. A fines del 2020 su capitalización bordaba los 50 millones de dólares, es decir, aumentó cerca del doble, después de un complicado año de pandemia. 
En base a la masiva vacunación que se está produciendo en todo el mundo contra el coronavirus, los especialistas aproximan que en EEUU, para mitad de año (2021), debería estar la mitad de la población vacunada. En Chile, para Julio-Agosto de este año, debiesemos tener cerca de un 70% de la población vacunada. Esto claramente incidirá en la libertad de las personas, permitiendo mayor movilización luego del fin de las cuarentenas y la vuelta a la vida "normal", y por lo tanto, mayor uso de apliciones como Uber.
Es por esto, que creo que será muy poco probable que su capitalización baje con respecto a la actual, sabiendo que todo apunta a que se termine el coronavirus. Tiene muchas posibilidades de aumentar, debido a que si todo funciona correctamente con el virus, Uber podría seguir con el crecimiento que viene desde fines del año pasado (cerca de un 50%). También podría mantenerse por que aún hay mucha incertidumbre mundial en muchos países, con las vacunas, nuevas sepas, y todo tipo de cosas que puedan hacernos volver a las cuarentenas, pero irían compensando los países que no estén confinados.

Según el sitio macrotrends (https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/UBER/uber-technologies/market-cap), el cual ilustra gráficamente la capitalización de Uber en el último año, actualmente uber capitaliza alrededor de 100 billones de dólares, lo cual representa casi el doble de lo que se logró en diciembre del 2020. Es imposible para mí no hacer el vínculo de estos números con el porcentaje de vacunación que existe hoy a nivel mundial contra el Covid-19. Podemos tomar la muestra de Estados Unidos, país que ha tenido un buen desempeño en cuanto este tema, lo cual representaría un escenario mas bien optimista en comparación con la situación mundial. Además, Uber se encuentra presente en este país desde hace alrededor de 12 años, entonces podemos utilizarlo como ejemplo.  Haciendo pronóstico sobre el nivel de vacunación que tendrá EEUU en Julio por ejemplo, si se mantiene al ritmo actual (casi 25% en 4 meses aprox.), podría haber un 50% de la población completamente vacunada, lo cual definitivamente significará cambios en la libertad de movimiento de las personas en el país, y más aún en diciembre de este año. En base a esto, hago la estimación de que en diciembre de 2021 la capitalización de Uber estará por sobre los 150 billones de dólares (40%), ya que se puede esperar que la gente tenga un mayor grado de libertad en ese momento, de acuerdo a la vacuna contra el Covid-19. Creo que este razonamiento esta bien planteado, ya que, llevándolo a algo mas concreto, Uber efectivamente a aumentado su capitalización desde que se comenzó el proceso de vacunación, entonces poniéndonos en el caso de que el resto de los países logran el nivel de vacunación adecuado, como lo esta haciendo EEUU, estos números planteados me hacen sentido.

Currently $105 billion, little changed from a few weeks ago even as C19 vaccinations have started to really kick in and people are traveling a lot more, a lot sooner, than a lot of us expected.  Therefore the current crowd odds in my opinion are a little bit underestimating the likelihood of the status quo ("More than $100 billion but less than $125 billion") being maintained.

Current stock price of Uber is 56 USD and the market cap is 98B USD.  Uber expects a quarterly profit in 3rd quarter 2021. At the same time, the fundamentals seem to be strong with analysts recommending a buy. Uber is favorably positioned in California with the Proposition 22 in the labor law. It has acquired alcohol delivery platform.  2021 seems recovery for Uber after US declares corona free with  a successful vaccination drive.
However, the long-term prospects are challenging:
1. Uber business is very margin thin.
2. There is not much innovation that will drive growth other than acquisitions.
3. It is a highly competitive business.
https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/uber
https://capital.com/uber-stock-forecast-for-2021#:~:text=Uber%20stock%20forecast%20for%202021%3A%20tailwinds%20prevail,Vaccination%20drive.

I just realized this stock only needs to fall about 26% to be in the less than $75 bil bucket. Definitely happening. It was there just 6 months ago. with inflation and interest rates going above 3% this year stocks like Uber that have been the recipients of the easy money are going to see the reverse effect.  And why would a company that has been around this long and never made a profit be worth anything? When things get tough people will turn to stocks that actually have a real value.

https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/UBER/financials/ A company thats never made any operating profit and despite sharp cuts of 2.6bn in R&D last year still has operating losses of 4.8bn.
Their revenues aren't going to come back to prepandemic levels anytime soon, so basically most of the share price appreciation that they have seen is down to low interest rates.
96bn valuation itself seems preposterous.
Betting on 3+% inflation by then, which will crash the market.

Uber certainly has been on a wild ride since going public in May 2019. The IPO set the valuation at about $82 billion. The market cap on Dec 31, 2019, saw that number shrink when Uber had a market cap of about $51 billion following a decline in the stock post-IPO. The first half of 2020 saw a massive decline in the stock down to a low of $14. However, the second-half rebound has shot the stock up to all-time new highs. The closing market cap for 2020 saw Uber pass its initial valuation with a market cap of about $89 billion. That has since grown to right around $104 billion currently. The daily market cap average since the IPO has been about $65 billion, so it would appear Uber is currently trending up.  What is driving the higher share prices? First off, Uber saw a strong rebound in its rideshare bookings in the second half of 2020. This seems to have given new life to the company. However, it appears Wall Street is more interested in some of their other segments. Their delivery segment was particularly strong in 2020 and outpaced its competitors. The purchase of Postmate and Drizzly seems to have positioned Uber to remain a market leader in goods delivery post-pandemic. Additionally, the company is exploring new delivery segments to get involved in. Finally, Prop 22 in California has seemingly taken some of their labor issues off the table in the short-run giving Uber a sigh of relief in a large market.  Wall Street seems extremely Bullish on the stock. A 40 Analyst survey had 32 Bullish, 6 Neutral, and 2 Bearish. Deutsche Bank has raised its price target to $80 (the highest of the bunch) for 2021 which would put the market cap at   $144 billion. That number seems a bit high, although attainable if they continue to see the growth of the last few months. The average target price right now appears to be about $61. That seems to be more reasonable. I think they have a 69% chance to hit a target price of $55-69, putting the cap at the $100-125 billion. I think there is a 13% chance the stock falls below $55 and a 17% chance the stock eclipses the $69. I think moving about the $80 target this year seems unlikely.

What is the stock worth of a company that has been around as long as Uber and has never made any money? Uber has yet to prove that it has a workable business model. It is kept alive by constant inflows of investor money. it is one of the babies of the stock market so as the stock market booms Uber will do fine but when the market crashes Uber will crash more than most. this is almost a question on how the stock market is going to do this year. Uber stock price it's not about fundamentals.

Uber's current market capitalization could be inflated or it may plateau at its current level. It is possible that Uber's market capitalization will increase significantly to $125 or $150 billion but it is unlikely. This will need to be revisited throughout the year since a lot can change if Uber introduces new technology, wins/loses lawsuits, or if new competitors enter the market. https://ycharts.com/companies/UBER/market_cap

Uber is false prophet and essentially premised on a few major things. 1. Regulatory arbitrage. It makes money by avoiding things like payroll taxes and having people working for it seen as temporary contractors. More and more governments are getting frustrated by this, especially when they are going to be scrambling for increased taxes soon. 2. Ubers stock is frothy and just over 100 billion at the moment, a lot of that is driven by hot cash floating around the market and the name recognition that Uber has - the silly money if you will. That will drop it below 100 billion when there is bad economic or other news in the next year. 3. Uber is only worth a high price if it has a plan to get rid of one of it's major costs (drivers). It doesn't. It's self driving R&D has been a shambles. It has little or no hope of being able to develop the tech to do that. Tesla and the others are so much further ahead. Uber is also too big to be bought out by a big car company.

Uber's current market capitalization reflects the impact of COVID-19 on travel generally and specifically people's use of public transportation and Uber. In 6 months, it is probable that more than 50% of the population of the US will have received the COVID-19 vaccine, this likely will lead to surge in travel and people going out, which will impact positively Uber's market capitalization.

I think Uber was positioned to be above $120B in 2020 prior to the pandemic. Revenues are stable and 4th quarter numbers will be very important to determine trend of revenue recovery or plateaued. Vaccinations will be critical to Uber's value for 2021.  Market recovery and Uber

Uber is a big company now, and the most likely outcome is roughly matching the S&P's expected outcome--with very fat tails of course
1/19/2021 - Current market cap = 99.3 B * (Average Price Target 60.68 / Current Price 56.3) = 107.02 plus

Current market cap of $102 is the baseline, with growth being the "normal" outcome. Therefore, the $100-$125 should be the most likely outcome and the distribution should look somewhat bell shaped. The tails may be relatively fat, although a 26% decline between now and December should be a low probability event. A 47% growth is also a long shot, although possible with a new product rollout. I'll increase the tail odds if things move in those directions.

Stock is highly volatile so I spread my bets. At the end of the year I believe the most important question for the company and its marketcap will not corona, or a vaccine but whether it will be able to turn a profit.

As always, current market cap (~100B$) should be the basis estimate. Few things particular to Uber compared to other listed companies :
- Uber is still a "young" company
- High potential (autonomous cars) but high risks (legal, financial) Market is currently very volatile. All things considered, "marginal" answers (<75B$ & >150B$) are not unlikely.
Current value ~$100 billion in a very frothy market (“irrational exuberance”).

Small but notable chance of something seriously going wrong / cashflow issue / scandal / market collapse that could crater the price Reasonable probability that vaccine-led resurgence in travel & economy lifts Q3/Q4 significantly

Linear regression trained on looking back the same number of trading days that remain until the end of the Question.  Assumes normal distribution of predicted values with mean of predicted value by linear regression on 12/31/21 and standard deviation of standard deviation of sample looking back the same number of trading days that remain until the end of the Question.
Inflation causes interest rates to rise causing a drop in extended asset values
It's "worth" ~$78 -$80 billion now, and it's growing during the pandemic time in almost every country in which they operate.
2020 was a good year for Uber, 2021 with traveling turning to some stability, will allow company growing, some adjustments in prices would push capitalization up.
